Bread wheat is one of three pillars on which the global food supply rests. Despite wheat's exceptional importance, a high quality draft sequence of the wheat genome is not available due primarily to its hybrid origin (polyploidy) and the enormous size of its genome. To assist the international bread wheat genome sequencing effort, a high quality draft of the genome of Aegilops tauschii, one of the three progenitors of bread wheat, will be produced. The large size and great complexity of the Ae. tauschii genome necessitate adopting the ordered-clone sequencing strategy for generating a high quality genome sequence draft. This strategy will involve the sequencing of about 50,000 bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clones harboring large fragments of Ae. tauschii DNA that have been ordered to represent the contiguous sequence of nucleotides in Ae. tauschii chromosomal DNA. Pools of BAC clones will be sequenced with a next generation DNA sequencing platform and assembled into long contiguous sequences. The correctness of the assembled sequences will be validated with a novel optical nanotechnique. Genes and transposable elements in the assembled sequences will be annotated. In this way, the sequence, location, and orientation of all genes and transposable elements in the Ae. tauschii genome will be determined.

The most immediate impact of the Ae. tauschii genome sequence produced by this project will be in predicting the location of genes in wheat and its relatives, thus accelerating progress in genome sequencing of wheat and its relatives and facilitating gene discovery and manipulation in these species through traditional breeding methods and biotechnology. The Ae. tauschii genome sequence will serve as a reference in analyses of genomic changes that have taken place in the wheat genome since wheat's origin, providing significant and fundamental contributions to the understanding of grass genome structure and evolution. Association of the more than 36,000 genes predicted within the draft genome sequence with biological functions will be a daunting task. For this reason, the project will engage the large research community interested in analyzing genes of Ae. tauschii in community-based manual gene annotation and graphical compilation of the results in the project database. To maximize the awareness about the project resources among the wheat breeders and other stakeholders, regular presentations/workshops of these resources will be made at professional meetings attended by wheat breeders. The project will also provide excellent interdisciplinary training for students and postdocs in plant genomics, bioinformatics, DNA sequencing and sequence assembly, validation, and analysis. Validated sequences of BAC contigs and sequences parsed to individual BAC clones will be deposited on a monthly basis to a project website (to be developed). All sequences will be deposited at the long-term NCBI repository and incorporated into the Gramene, GrainGenes, and MIPS comparative databases. Individual BAC clones or their groups from the nine libraries of Ae. tauschii AL8/78 and the minimal tiling path (MTP) across the contigs are publicly available and distributed through http://probes.pw.usda.gov/WheatDMarker/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wheat provides about one-fifth of the calories and protein in the human diet globally and, in the US, it ranks third behind maize and soybean in significance as an agricultural commodity. At the start of this project, a complete sequence of the wheat genome was not available. The absence of this genomic tool diminished the utility of the existing wheat genetic, cytogenetic, and genomic resources and greatly hindered efficient discovery and isolation of biologically and economically important genes from wheat and its relatives. These factors limited progress in wheat breeding and biotechnology and contributed to the fact that wheat lagged behind maize, sorghum, and soybean in the rate of yield increase.

Bread wheat is a stable hybrid (technically polyploid) of three diploid species. This project was to focus on one of the three wheat progenitors, Aegilops tauschii, leveraging the various existing Ae. tauschii genomic resources towards producing a high-quality sequence of its genome. The Ae. tauschii genome, like the wheat genome, is large and complex compared to the plant species for which genomes had been sequenced at the start of this project. To sequence the Ae. tauschii genome, we utilized dense genetic and physical maps we developed from prior NSF support, and the emerging technology of nano-scale optical genome mapping (using the optical mapping platform of Bionano Inc.). We also combined several sequencing approaches and utilized short-read sequencing platforms and a new long-read sequencing platform (from Pacific Biosciences, Inc.). With these advanced technologies, we produced a high-quality genome sequence assembly for Ae. tauschii and annotated in it genes, pseudogenes, and transposable elements. Near the end of the project, we were able to extend our strategy to produce a high-quality genome sequence assembly for wheat too. We demonstrated the exceptional utility of optical genome maps for validating genome assembly and producing reference-quality genome sequences. Aligning optical maps onto DNA sequences afforded us with the unprecedented opportunity to detect nearly all differences in the structure between the Ae. tauschii genome and the wheat genome, including those structural differences located in regions of the genome with highly repetitive DNA sequences.

With the tools and strategies we developed, we were able to analyze the structure and evolution of the Ae. tauschii and wheat genomes and deduce the rates and patterns of genome evolution in wheat, its close relatives, and other cereals. Ae. tauschii contributed to wheat most of the genes for the bread-making properties of wheat flour. We identified and characterized 31 of these genes in the Ae. tauschii genome sequence. Ae. tauschii is also an important source of genes for resistance of wheat to various diseases. We discovered 1,762 resistance genes in the Ae. tauschii genome, classified them, and analyzed their distribution in the genome.

All results of the project have been made available to the broader scientific community through publications, presentations, and publicly accessible databases. Our demonstration that the Ae. tauschii genome sequence provides a framework for meta-analyses of genes affecting quantitative traits in wheat and other cereals and the development of statistical tests for these analyses broadened the impact of the project. The multidiscipline nature of the project has provided an exceptional training environment in cutting-edge sequencing and optical mapping technology, bioinformatics, statistics, and genetic analyses for undergraduate (14) and graduate (7) students, postdoctoral scholars (5), and junior scientists (8) working on the project. We held two training workshops to extend the project?s gene and transposable element annotation strategies and the optical genome mapping technology to graduate students and postdoctoral scholars from outside the project.
